title-group.article-title: Retrospective Analysis of the Survivability of Absorbable Versus Nonabsorbable Subtalar Joint Arthroereisis Implants

article-meta.aff: Weil Foot & Ankle Institute, Des Plaines, Illinois (JRB, EEK, LW, LSW)

author-notes.corresp: Jeffrey R. Baker, DPM, FACFAS, Weil Foot & Ankle Institute, 1455 E Golf Road, Des Plaines, IL 60016; e-mail: jrb@weil4feet.com.

abstract.p: Subtalar joint arthroereisis is a surgical modality that has been shown to be an effective procedure for flexible flatfoot in both pediatric and adult populations. Despite advances in understanding its mechanics and function, complication and implant removal rates remain as high as 30% to 40%. Analysis was performed to determine the survivability of 2 subtalar joint arthroereisis implants, absorbable and nonabsorbable, used alone and in combination with other procedures in both the adult and pediatric populations. The 95 total arthroereisis procedures were analyzed in several major categories: absorbable implants versus nonabsorbable implants and adult versus pediatric patients. Each major group was then further subdivided to create further subgroups: absorbable isolated procedures, absorbable combined procedures, nonabsorbable isolated procedures, and nonabsorbable combined procedures. The overall survival rates were 83% for absorbable implants and 81% for nonabsorbable implants. A total of 11 (17%) absorbable implants and 6 (19%) nonabsorbable implants were removed, respectively, at an average of 9 months and 23 months postoperatively. When used alone and in combination with other procedures, 36% and 13% of absorbable implants and 18% and 19% of nonabsorbable implants, respectively, were removed. When comparing adult versus pediatric populations, the overall survival rates of the absorbable and nonabsorbable implants were 81% for absorbable implants and 79% for nonabsorbable implants in the adult population and 85% for absorbable implants and 100% for nonabsorbable implants in the pediatric population.
Level of Evidence: Therapeutic, Level III; Retrospective comparative series

disp-quote.p: “Many treatment modalities, both conservative and surgical, have been developed and used to address the symptomatic flexible flatfoot.”

body.p: Flexible flatfoot is a common condition with an incidence of 5% in children and adults.1 Symptomatic patients can experience anywhere from generalized fatigue of the foot, ankle, and leg to debilitating pain that interferes with daily activities. Many treatment modalities, both conservative and surgical, have been developed and used to address the symptomatic flexible flatfoot.

Subtalar joint arthroereisis is a surgical modality that has been shown to be an effective procedure for addressing flexible flatfoot in both pediatric and adult populations.2-11 The goal of the procedure is to reduce but not eliminate excessive hindfoot motion.9,11-14 The excessive motion, or hyperpronation, allows the talus to pronate on the calcaneus during the gait cycle without adequate resupination prior to heel off.3,15

Many different techniques and implants have been described and used for subtalar joint arthroereisis over the years. These differ by surgical technique, placement of the motion blocking mechanism, implant shape, and material. Despite controversies concerning the proper technique and implant to use, the concept of controlling excess motion has been widely accepted.

This concept of limiting the subtalar joint motion was first described by Chambers16 in 1946 with the insertion of an autologous bone graft into the sinus tarsi to prevent the forward migration of the talus. Others modified this technique by using the bone graft to open the sinus tarsi,17 using temporary extra-articular staples to lengthen the joint,5 or using permanent extra-articular staples with or without bone graft.18 In 1974, Subotnick19 became the first surgeon to use an arthroereisis implant made of silicone elastomer in the sinus tarsi to limit talar migration on the calcaneus. After this, implants made from polyethylene (STA-peg, Wright Medical, Arlington, TN) and titanium alloy (Maxwell-Brancheau Arthroereisis, Integra Life Sciences/KMI, Carlsbad, CA) were quickly introduced as preferable alternatives to silicone implants.

Despite advances in understanding the mechanics and function of subtalar arthroereisis, complication and implant removal rates remain as high as 30% to 40%.10,20 Reported complications include discomfort, malposition, extrusion/loosening, breakage, lack of correction, overcorrection, and persistent sinus tarsi pain and tenderness.2,5-10,21-23 Most surgeons are of the opinion that removal of the implant is the standard of care to address these complications. The purpose of our study was to analyze the survivability of 2 subtalar joint arthroereisis implants used alone as well as with other adjunctive procedures in patients who had a documented follow-up of at least 12 months. The adjunctive procedure(s) performed were calcaneal osteotomy, flexor digitorum longus transfer, gastrocnemius recession, Kidner procedure, medial cuneiform osteotomy, navicular-cuneiform arthrodesis, posterior tibial tendon repair, posterior tibial tendon tenosynovectomy, spring ligament repair, tendoachilles lengthening, and tibialis anterior transfer.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A retrospective review was conducted on adult and pediatric patients who had a subtalar joint arthroereisis procedure performed by multiple surgeons at 1 institution either in isolation or combined with other procedures through a standard technique (Figures 1-5) between January 2002 and December 2010. A total of 95 patients (66 adult and 29 pediatric) were identified who fulfilled the following inclusion criteria: use of a specific subtalar joint arthroereisis implant, absorbable (poly-L-lactic acid [PLLA] bioabsorbable implant Arthrex, Naples, FL) or nonabsorbable (Kalix Nedeal SA, Lyon, France), with complete medical records, and a follow-up of at least 12 months. Patients who had other subtalar joint arthroereisis implants, other procedures performed for a flexible flatfoot without the use of a subtalar joint arthroereisis, incomplete medical records, or follow-up of less than 12 months were excluded from this study.

caption.p: Correct Final Placement of the Arthroereisis Device.
A Postoperative MRI Showing Proper Placement of the Arthroereisis Device.

sec.p: Medical records were reviewed, and the following parameters were recorded: age of patient at the time of implantation, implant used (absorbable vs nonabsorbable), adjunctive procedures performed, implant removal, and time to implant removal. All data were recorded and statistical analysis performed.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The 95 total arthroereisis procedures were divided into several major groups: 63 absorbable and 32 nonabsorbable implants and 66 adult and 29 pediatric patients. Each major group was then further subdivided to create subgroups: absorbable isolated procedures, absorbable combined procedures, nonabsorbable isolated procedures, and nonabsorbable combined procedures (Tables 1-3).

caption.p: Total Results (Total of 95 Implants Used in the Combined Adult and Pediatric Population)
Adult Results (Total of 66 Implants Used in the >18-Year-Old Population)
Pediatric Results (Total of 29 Implants Used in the <18-Year-Old Population)

sec.p: When looking at total patient numbers, the absorbable implant group had a total of 63 arthroereisis devices used; 11 (17%) were isolated procedures, and 52 (83%) were used in combination with other procedures. In the isolated procedure group, the average age of the patient population was 30 years (range = 13-56 years). A total of 4 (36%) implants were removed at an average of 9 months postoperatively. There were 52 absorbable arthroereisis implants used in combination with other procedures. The patient population of this group were on average 35 years (range = 9-73 years) old. In this group, 7 (13%) of the implants were removed at an average of 11 months postoperatively. The nonabsorbable implant group had a total of 32 arthroereisis devices used; 11 (34%) were isolated procedures, and 21 (66%) were used in combination with other procedures. In the isolated procedure group, the average age of the patient population was 47 years (range = 16-80 years), and 2 (18%) of the implants were removed at an average of 50 months postoperatively. A total of 21 nonabsorbable arthroereisis implants were used in combination with other procedures. The patient population of this group were, on average, 47 years (range = 11-72 years) old. A total of 4 (19%) implants were removed at an average of 9 months postoperatively.

When comparing the adult versus the pediatric population, the overall survival rate of the absorbable and nonabsorbable implants was 81% for absorbable implants and 79% for nonabsorbable implants in the adult population and 85% for absorbable implants and 100% for nonabsorbable implants in the pediatric population.

In regard to implant removal, 16 of the 17 total implants removed were removed secondary to pain at the sinus tarsi. One patient, a 44-year-old in the absorbable isolated group, had the implant removed 15 months postimplantation secondary to implant breakage. A complete list of patient parameters can be found in Table 4.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Flexible flatfoot is a relatively common condition of the lower extremity.1 Debate still exists over the optimal treatment for this condition because there is often more than 1 correct treatment option for any given patient. Subtalar joint arthroereisis has been shown to be an effective procedure for both pediatric and adult populations.2-11

Current arthroereisis techniques are the product of more than 50 years of evolution in surgical treatments directed at correcting flexible flatfoot deformity by altering the alignment of the talus and changing the moment arm about the talonavicular joint.10,11 Evidence supports a multitude of reasons for arthroereisis failure and subsequent removal.

Zaret and Myerson,9 in 2003, published their findings using the MBA implant on 43 feet, with 31 inserted in children and 12 in adults. The authors reported that 7 patients complained of postoperative pain and attributed this to implant impingement on the posterior facet or insertion of an incorrectly sized implant. Four patients had their implants removed.

In 2007, Schon10 attempted to explain such complications associated with the MBA implant by studying the shape of the sinus tarsi on CT scan. His findings demonstrated that the sinus tarsi is more conical than cylindrical. Given that MBA implants are cylindrical, Schon suggested that complications associated with such implants could be attributed to the conflicting shapes causing an uneven distribution of forces and, therefore, resulting in pain.

The Kalix implant (Nedeal SA, Lyon, France) was designed in an attempt to reduce complications caused by implants not shaped according to the anatomical shape of the sinus tarsi. Viladot et al8 in 2003 reported their results on the insertion of this implant into 21 patients with stage II posterior tibial dysfunction. Of the 19 patients, 17 were satisfied at their final follow-up (average of 27.31 months), with an average improvement in the American Orthopedic Foot and Ankle Society score from 47.2 preoperatively to 81.6 postoperatively. Two implants had to be removed because of pain; however, both patients stated that they would undergo the surgery again.

In this study, we used a PLLA bioabsorbable implant. This PLLA bioabsorbable implant was introduced in an attempt to reduce complications caused by nonabsorbable inappropriately shaped implants. The bioabsorbable implant is thought to act as an “internal orthotic,” placing the hindfoot in proper alignment. It is hoped that this, over time, would allow for adaptation of the soft-tissue structures, thus diminishing the deforming forces that created the painful flexible flatfoot. The absorbable nature of the implant was theorized to have significant advantages over a standard nonabsorbable implant. The implant is thought to exhibit favorable degradation characteristics, which ensure that strength is maintained during the critical first 12 weeks of healing.24-27 The radiolucent PLLA implant gradually redistributes forces associated with weight bearing, and with this, there is a decreased incidence of removal after initial implantation.25 With an absorbable implant, the corrected position is held as the implant degrades over time, requiring less need for removal of the implant.6 The implant also creates a soft end feel when the foot is maximally pronated, decreasing breakdown of the subtalar joint from weight-bearing activities.

Bioabsorbable implants have many applications in the medical field. The characteristics of bioabsorbable interference screws used for anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction are found throughout the literature. Bioabsorbable screws are manufactured from lactic acid polymers or lactic acid/glycolic acid copolymers.28 Various types of materials are available in the market for designing bioabsorbable screws and include polyglycolic acid, polylactic acid, polyparadioxanone, poly-L-lactide, and several other stereoisomers of lactic acid. The clinical difference in these implants is the absorption rate and local tissue reaction. Resorption time of the implants is based on molecular weight, crystallinity, the size of the implant, and the vascularity of the surrounding tissue.29 The material is broken down by hydrolic chain scission and eliminated as carbon dioxide and water by respiration.29 Major advantages of the use of bioabsorbable implants include decreased interference during magnetic resonance imaging and absence of need for a second surgical procedure for hardware removal.25-28,30-33 Disadvantages and possible complications include screw breakage, inflammatory and foreign body reactions, cyst formation, and local bone lysis.25-28,30-33

Four basic tenets as described by Speer and Warren34 apply to bioabsorbable implants. The implant needs adequate fixation strength, the material must have the ability to maintain stability while tissue healing is occurring, the material should not resorb so slowly that breakage and migration are possible, and the materials must not cause reactions of any kind. The PLLA implant used with the aforementioned procedure has a low complication rate because of its high molecular weight construct. This higher molecular weight slows the resorption rate, decreasing the amount of lactic acid end products.35 Morgan et al29 removed a PLLA interference screw 30 months after implantation and studied its composition. The screw and a surrounding bone block were removed for investigation. The implant was noted to retain 25% of its original molecular weight. No inflammatory reactions or cyst formations were noted in any of the surrounding tissues. McGuire et al27 performed a post mortem evaluation 4 months after implantation of a PLLA interference screw for ACL reconstruction. The results of their evaluation showed no signs of inflammatory reaction, cystic changes, or foreign body reactions. A 3.5-year explant of a PLLA interference screw showed a reduction of 94% of molecular weight (A. Holloway, Director of Research, Arthrex, Naples, FL, professional correspondence).

Several reported isolated complications with PLLA interference screws are noted in the literature. MacDonald et al32 reported a case of a fragment of a PLLA interference screw presenting as a loose body in the knee joint; 11 months after surgery, the patient complained of edema and persistent pain in the knee with activity. Arthroscopic evaluation revealed a loose body fragment from the implant in the lateral compartment. It was hypothesized that the screw was not fully seated into the osseous tunnel, causing the head to break. Malhan et al35 reported a case of tibial cyst formation 12 months after ACL reconstruction with the use of a PLLA interference screw. Curettage of the cyst with removal of its contents provided relief of symptoms. No microorganisms were cultured from the area, and pathological evaluation showed a few giant cells and macrophages. The crystalline nature of PLLA implants may cause reactive synovitis and irritation over time during breakdown of the screw resulting from particle fragments in the surrounding tissue.25 These particles have been noted to persist for up to 6 years postimplantation.

Absorbable implant use for subtalar joint arthroereisis is not a new concept. Giannini reported the use of PLLA bioabsorbable implants for subtalar joint arthroereisis for juvenile flexible flatfoot as early as 1996 (Lowell Scott Weil Sr, DPM, personal communication, March 2004). Then, he along with colleagues reported on a 4-year follow-up of 21 children with bilateral flexible flatfoot treated with an absorbable subtalar joint arthroereisis and adjunctive procedures as necessary.6 There was a significant decrease in discomfort, from 81% preoperatively to only 5% postoperatively. Mean clinical and radiographic parameters all significantly improved at follow-up. Complications noted included minor fragmentation of the implant material that spontaneously resorbed over time. Subsequent follow-up magnetic resonance imaging studies performed over the course of follow-up did not reveal any bone changes, sinus formation, or internal derangement to the sinus tarsi.

A report on subtalar arthroereisis by Cook et al21 focused on risk factors for explantation. Of all factors analyzed in this propensity-matched ]review, a postoperative increase in the talocalcaneal angle (anteroposterior radiograph) and calcaneal-cuboid angle were associated with increased risk of explantation. They concluded that the arthroereisis does not correct every deformity in the flatfoot, and proper patient selection is essential.

Our study compares the survivability of 2 different subtalar joint arthroereisis implants in a large population that includes adult and pediatric patients. Absorbable implants, when used alone, had a higher rate of removal than when used with other procedures (36%). This may be a result of the postoperative protocol used for isolated arthroereisis procedures. Patients receiving an isolated implant (absorbable or nonabsorbable) were allowed earlier return to activity, potentially causing problems with the implant (ie, loosening and breakage) in the absorbable group secondary to suboptimal seeding of the implant within the sinus tarsi because of its inherent absorbable characteristics. The postoperative protocol for the isolated groups was partial weight bearing with a below-the-knee boot and crutch gait assistance for 10 days postprocedure and then a progression to closed-toe athletic shoe gear with no aggressive walking or athletic activity for the next 3 weeks. At approximately 4 weeks postprocedure, patients were allowed to return to all shoe gear and activity as tolerated. For the combined procedure subgroups, the postoperative treatment course was based on the postoperative protocol necessary for the adjunctive procedure(s) performed, which were more conservative in nature. The rates of removal of the absorbable implant when used with adjunctive procedures (13%) as well as the nonabsorbable implants when used alone and in combination with other procedures (18% and 19% respectively) were all below the 30% to 40% removal rate reported in the literature.10,20

When the adult and pediatric patient populations were isolated, the rate of removal in the adult group mirrored the results found in the total patient population in all subgroups. In the pediatric population, the highest removal rate was also present in the absorbable isolated subgroup (40%), with decreased removal rates noted in the other categories.

The strengths of the study include a large patient population with long-term follow-up. The weaknesses of the study include the retrospective design, variable patient population (large age range with adult and pediatric patients), and the lack of inclusion of radiographic parameters concerning the amount of correction obtained for each of the subgroups.

Subtalar joint arthroereisis has been documented over time to be a viable and simple procedure for the correction of the flexible flatfoot in children and acquired flatfoot deformity in adults. The advantages of the absorbable procedure include ease of technique, minimal morbidity, and progressive correction of the deformity while the implant degrades. Although multiple factors are part of a good assessment of the flexible flatfoot deformity, it is clear that arthroereisis maintains a place in the treatment algorithm.
